title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text: This guide explains the difference between Generative BI (Gen BI) and Agentic Analytics, with examples, use cases, roadmap, and example architectures.

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text: This guide explains the difference between Generative BI (Gen BI) and Agentic Analytics, with examples, use cases, roadmap, and example architectures.

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
2 🔷 What’s the difference?








Feature
Generative BI
Agentic Analytics




Definition
Use of generative AI (e.g., LLMs) to make BI conversational and accessible
Use of autonomous AI agents to monitor, reason, and act


Focus
Natural language querying & insight generation
Autonomous problem-solving & action-taking


User Role
User asks → system answers
Agent acts → user reviews/overrides


Tech Foundation
LLMs, NLP, vector search
Agents, reasoning, orchestration, planning


Goal
Democratize data insights
Proactively optimize KPIs & take actions

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
3 🌟 Examples

3.1 Generative BI
✅ User asks: “Show me revenue trends by region last quarter.”
✅ NLP translates → SQL → dashboard or insight.
✅ Tools: Microsoft Copilot in Power BI, Tableau GPT, ThoughtSpot Sage, Looker.


3.2 Agentic Analytics
✅ Agent monitors churn → detects anomaly → runs analysis → recommends retention campaign → optionally triggers it.
✅ Tools: LangChain Agents, AutoGen, CrewAI, IBM Watson Decision Support.

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
4 🏦 Use Cases in Banking







Generative BI
Agentic Analytics




Self-service dashboards and reports
Continuous KPI monitoring and autonomous adjustment


Natural-language queries on deposits, loans, churn
Detects anomalies and launches root cause analysis


Automated dashboards and narratives
Adjusts operations or triggers workflows autonomously

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
5 📈 Roadmap: Maturity Journey








Stage
Description
Example Outcome




1. Traditional BI
Static dashboards
“I can see my KPIs weekly.”


2. Self-Service BI
Business users build own reports
“I can slice & dice myself.”


3. Generative BI
NLP-driven, automated insights
“I can ask anything & get answers.”


4. Augmented BI
System suggests anomalies/trends
“It highlights what matters.”


5. Agentic Analytics
Agents monitor & act autonomously
“It adjusts operations proactively.”

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
6 🪜 Example Architectures

6.1 Generative BI
[User]
   ↓
[LLM/NLP]
   ↓
[Semantic Layer + SQL Generator]
   ↓
[Data Warehouse]
   ↓
[BI Tool / Dashboard]



6.2 Agentic Analytics
               [Agent Framework]
                     ↓
   [Planner + Reasoner + Memory + Tools]
                     ↓
 [Data Warehouse + Real-time Streams]
                     ↓
 [BI Tools] & [Action APIs] & [Workflow Automation]
                     ↓
        [Feedback & Continuous Loop]

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
7 🛠️ Key Building Blocks
✅ Data Layer: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift — clean, documented.
✅ Semantic Layer: Business-friendly metrics & dimensions (e.g., dbt, AtScale).
✅ LLM Integration: Embedded in BI tools (for Gen BI) or orchestrated (for agents).
✅ Orchestration Layer: LangChain, AutoGen.
✅ Action Layer: API connectors & workflow automation (e.g., Zapier, Airflow).

title: Generative BI vs. Agentic Analytics
text:
8 🔷 In short

Generative BI = “Talk to your data.”
Agentic Analytics = “Your data solves problems for you.”


If you’d like, you can also: - 📄 Add visual diagrams of these architectures. - 🚀 Build a tailored roadmap for your organization. - 📋 Map these ideas to specific vendors & open-source tools.
Let me know if you’d like help with any of these!

title: Agentic AI
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is evolving rapidly, and one of the most exciting developments is the emergence of Agentic AI. Unlike traditional AI systems that simply respond to input, Agentic AI systems can reason, plan, act, and adapt autonomously. This blog post will walk you through the basics of Agentic AI—what it is, how it works, how it differs from other AI approaches, and why it matters.



Agentic AI refers to intelligent systems that act with intent, autonomy, and adaptability to achieve defined goals. Unlike traditional AI, these agents not only respond to commands but also plan, decide, and act proactively — often without step-by-step human direction.
They can perceive their environment, break down complex objectives into manageable tasks, interact with tools and APIs, and adapt their behavior based on feedback and context. In essence, they function as proactive collaborators, not just reactive assistants.
Google Cloud defines agentic AI as systems with memory, planning, and tool-use capabilities, operating in dynamic feedback loops. IBM and McKinsey emphasize their role as organizational actors — capable of taking initiative, making decisions aligned with goals, and integrating seamlessly with human teams.












AI Type
Behavior
Limitation




Traditional AI
Rule-based or ML-based automation
Rigid, task-specific


Generative AI
Generates text, images, audio, or video using LLMs, diffusion, GANs, etc.
Reactive: one prompt → one response


Agentic AI
Goal-oriented planning and action
Proactive, multi-step autonomy



IBM describes the progression clearly: generative AI creates content across modalities, while agentic AI follows through on tasks by interpreting ambiguous instructions, planning multi-step workflows, and taking initiative.
McKinsey further notes that agentic systems assume decision-making responsibilities by incorporating context, risk, and organizational goals into their actions.




Agentic AI follows a systematic process where each step is powered by key capabilities built into the system:

Perceive — The agent collects and analyzes data from sensors, databases, and digital interfaces using its memory to understand the environment and identify key entities or patterns.
Reason — Using a reasoning engine (often an LLM) and contextual memory, the agent formulates plans, decomposes goals, and decides on the best course of action.
Plan — Supported by its planner, the agent organizes the tasks into a logical sequence to achieve the objective.
Act — The agent executes the planned tasks by interacting with external systems and APIs through its tool use capabilities.
Learn — Through a continuous feedback loop and updated memory, the agent monitors outcomes, learns from them, and refines its models to improve future performance.

This integrated view shows how the components are not separate modules, but enablers embedded within the steps of the agent’s workflow, making the system proactive, adaptive, and goal-oriented.




Agentic AI is already transforming industries, delivering measurable benefits and enabling capabilities beyond traditional and generative AI. Below are illustrative examples and data showing how organizations are adopting and benefiting from these systems.


In financial services, agentic AI systems orchestrate the loan origination journey end-to-end, going beyond traditional AI workflows or generative AI insights. These agents: - Ingest real-time data from macroeconomic trends, customer behavior, regulatory changes, and sentiment analysis. - Assess creditworthiness, adjust pricing, recommend optimal product bundles, and flag anomalies for human review. - Collaborate with other agents in fraud detection, compliance, and capital allocation to optimize outcomes.
In operations and customer service, agents dynamically rebalance workloads across call centers, resolve customer inquiries with contextual and emotionally intelligent responses, escalate only when human judgment is needed, and detect emerging patterns (e.g., loan performance divergence) before humans are even aware.
In multiagent systems, a decentralized network of agents collaborate — one assessing creditworthiness, another modeling risk exposure, and a third ensuring compliance — working together to optimize customer journeys and manage trade-offs in real time.











Industry Sector
Approx. Adoption (%)
Example Companies




Technology & Software
~24%
Microsoft, Salesforce, BMC


Financial Services
~18%
JPMorgan, ING, Klarna


Retail & Consumer Goods
~16%
Best Buy, McDonald’s, Pets at Home


Healthcare & Life Sciences
~12%
HCA Healthcare, Hackensack Meridian


Professional Services
~10%
McKinsey, Accenture, Thomson Reuters


Travel & Hospitality
~8%
IHG Hotels, Alaska Airlines


Manufacturing & Industrial
~6%
Continental, Fortenova Group


Other
~6%
Various














Use Case Category
Approx. Adoption (%)
Reported Benefits




Customer Service & Support
~35%
12–30% faster resolution, 20–40% lower costs, higher satisfaction


Internal Operations
~25%
30–90% time savings, 25–50% cost savings, reduced errors


Sales & Marketing
~20%
9–21% revenue increase, 15–25% higher conversions


Security & Fraud Detection
~12%
70% fraud reduction, faster detection, improved accuracy


Specialized Industry Solutions
~8%
Industry-specific improvements, compliance gains







Microsoft: ~9.4% revenue increase per seller, 20% more closed deals
JPMorgan: ~70% fraud reduction
McKinsey client: ~90% reduction in onboarding lead time, ~30% drop in administrative workload


Source: Data adapted from Bornet et al., (2024), Agentic Artificial Intelligence.






With great autonomy comes greater responsibility—and risk.

Unintended Autonomy: Agents may act without proper oversight
Bias and Hallucinations: Decisions may be based on flawed or biased reasoning
Privacy Concerns: Tool-using agents must handle sensitive data with care
Brand Consistency: In customer contexts, inappropriate tone or overpersonalization can damage trust

IBM warns that agentic systems magnify the impact of AI errors:
> “A flawed generative response might misinform—a flawed agentic response might act on that misinformation.”




McKinsey, IBM, and Google recommend strategies to mitigate risks:

Bounded Autonomy: Define task scope and tool permissions
Human-in-the-loop: Require approvals for high-stakes decisions
Audit Trails: Log all agent actions for transparency and review
Brand & Tone Governance: Use tone filters for customer-facing agents
Scenario Testing: Evaluate agent behavior in simulated environments
Collaborative Governance: Assign oversight responsibilities to cross-functional teams





From the Agentic Artificial Intelligence book: - Start with pilot programs in controlled environments - Use hybrid human–AI workflows to maintain oversight while leveraging automation - Scale gradually while building internal support through demonstrated success - Encourage agents and employees to learn from each other for continuous improvement




Agentic AI is more than just a new technology—it’s a paradigm shift:

From task execution to task ownership
From tools to teammates
From command-response to goal-driven collaboration

This will reshape work in both structure and culture. As McKinsey notes, organizations must evolve to become agentic themselves: more decentralized, flexible, and responsive.

“Agentic AI won’t just change how work is done—it will change what work means.”





Agentic AI blends the creativity of generative models with the initiative of autonomous systems. It’s already transforming workflows, customer experiences, and decision-making processes across industries.
To lead in this new era, organizations must not only deploy agentic systems but also redesign how humans and machines work together—with safety, purpose, and adaptability.
Stay tuned for more deep dives on tools, design patterns, and real-world examples.





Google Cloud. (2024). What are AI agents?

IBM Think. (2024). What is Agentic AI?

IBM Think. (2024). Agentic AI vs. Generative AI

McKinsey & Company. (2024). When can AI make good decisions? The rise of AI corporate citizens

McKinsey & Company. (2024). The future of work is agentic

McKinsey & Company. (2024). The future of customer experience: Embracing agentic AI

Bornet, et al. (2024). Agentic Artificial Intelligence. Selected pages.
